Fig. 1 : Oxygenated aliphatic and aromatic regions of Pepper lignin isolated from sugarcane bagasse fibers in HSQC spectra. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 A. Yield of monophenols from lignin oxidation in different synthetic air pressures. Squares are related to the total aldehydes and ketones yield. Lines are used as guides to the eye. *No synthetic air was added, 1 bar at the beginning of the reaction is the atmospheric pressure. B. FE for the individual detected monoaromatic products and total aldehydes and ketones. Lines are added as guides for the eye. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Representative SEM images of the fresh catalyst (A), and residual catalyst obtained after the LEOR (B) and after LTOR at psin air = 5 bar (C). Insert 5000 x zoom in the lower right. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Electrochemical surface area variation (%) regarding the applied potential for the LEOR. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Raman spectra were obtained on the thermo- (A) and electrocatalysts (B), being in A ex-situ and B, in situ measurements. The full width at half maximum (FWHM) obtained from the Ag bands in A and B are compared in C. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 EIS data obtained in 3 g L−1 lignin solution in 2 mol L−1 KOH supporting electrolyte for the CuO material. A. Full frequency range measurement at open circuit potential (around 0.5 VRHE), red dots, equivalent electrochemical circuit (EEC) inserted and related fit presented as blue line. B. High frequency (100 – 1 kHz) data obtained during the mf-MS measurement, red dots, equivalent electrochemical circuit (EEC) inserted, and related fit presented as the blue line. C. Mott-Schottky plots are presented as examples for before (yellow points) and after (green points) the electrochemical polarization at 1.65 VRHE, with the related linear fits and slopes presented. D. Oxygen vacancies population variation due to the LEOR. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Data related to LEOR. A. j/E profile obtained for the drop-cast CuO electrode in lignin 3 g L−1 in 2 mol L−1 KOH, potential perturbation program inserted. Zoom in on the hysteretic region inserted. B. Polarization curve obtained from the I/t data in Fig. S1. Tafel slope inserted. Fig. 7 Scheme 1 Proposed mechanism for lignin oxidation. A: proposed mechanism for the aldehydes production. B: proposed mechanism for the ketones production. Scheme 1 Adapted from [15]. Biorefinery is gaining attention as a way to obtain several high-value products in a green approach. Biomass can be used to obtain fuels, like ethanol. The waste, rich in lignins, can be (electro)chemically transformed into monophenols and other fuels, like hydrogen. This macromolecule has a complex structure and the optimization of (electro)catalysts for its depolymerization is difficult, mainly because the lack of fundamental knowledge. Because of this, we decided to compare thermo and electrochemical catalysis, using identical reaction liquor and catalyst. The products were identified and quantified by GC-FID. Mild oxidative conditions generated more aldehydes, independently if it was under electrochemical conditions or not. To explore eventual mechanistic similarities, we investigated the catalyst by Raman spectroscopy and electronic microscopy. By them, a similar behavior was observed, the particles were less coalesced and the CuO-related bands were narrowed. After, by Mott-Schottky analysis, the oxygen vacancies were identified as the active sites. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Lignin oxidation reaction Electrocatalysis Thermocatalyis Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biorefinery has gained increasing attention as a sustainable alternative to the traditional petrochemical industry, since converts biomass into a variety of valuable products such as fuels, chemicals, and materials [1,2]. The use of lignocellulose and its main components, cellulose, hemicelluloses, and lignin, is promising for being non-edible, abundant, renewable and an alternative for the use of fossil fuels. However, even though processes for the use of cellulose and hemicelluloses have been extensively studied [3,4], the valorization of lignin, the most abundant natural aromatic source in the world [5–7], remains a key challenge to unlock the success of biorefinery [2,8]. Most of the commercially available lignin nowadays is a by-product of the pulp and paper industry and is normally burned to generate vapor thermoelectricity and recovery chemicals. Lignins isolated from agro-industrial waste, e.g. to produce 2nd generation ethanol, have the same fate. Being an abundant and renewable aromatic macromolecule, the depolymerization of lignins can be used for mono phenolic compound production. Different methods have been investigated leading to a variety of products [9–12]. Oxidation is a very promising approach and the products, such as vanillin, are value-added chemicals generated with commercial applicability [7,13–15]. The lignin oxidation reaction (LOR) can be carried out in different systems, from alkaline solutions to acidic biphasic media, with oxygen or nitrobenzene, in the presence or absence of a catalyst [13,14,16,17]. The reaction mechanism has been studied for different reaction media and it is believed that the oxidation of lignin follows a two-electrons mechanism, even when different oxidants are used ( Scheme 1) [18–20]. The proposed mechanism starts with an oxidant removing one electron from the phenolate anion (II), forming the phenoxy radical (III). From (III), a second electron, together with a proton, is abstracted leading to (IV). Cγ is then oxidized to an aldehyde (V) which leads to the cleavage of Cα-Cβ and the formation of the desired product (VI) through a retro-aldol reaction. Minor yields of by-products, such as methyl ketones or carboxylic acids, which are commonly obtained alongside with (VI) when Cα is oxidized to the carbonyl group instead of Cγ, leading to (VII), and the retro-aldol step leads to the cleavage of the Cβ-Cγ bond, as shown in Scheme 1 B [15,19,20]. The existence of a radical in aqueous media is still not fully comprehended, since the presence of solvent molecules should be enough to shorten its lifetime, and probably block the reaction pathway. However, the use of heterogeneous catalysts, such as CuO, can be responsible for the stabilization of those intermediates by chemical interactions. The presence of these heterogeneous catalysts based on metals increases the mono phenolic yield by a factor of 1.5–2.0 [15]. However, even though oxides of different metals can result in similar monophenols yield, optimal catalyst oxidative properties should be selected. The catalyst needs to oxidize II to III but should not oxidize VI (Scheme 1). Considering this, a good and quite selective catalyst is copper (II) oxide. It presents a good selectivity for the obtention of aldehydes in yields like the observed in oxidation with nitrobenzene, which is known as one of the best oxidants for lignins [15]. In the electrochemical context, Cu-based materials are not common catalysts for lignin oxidation, being Ni, Co, Fe, and Pb-based materials the most used ones [21–24]. Cu and its oxides are more commonly used as a cathodic catalyst for lignin depolymerization [25]. However, enzymes containing Cu active sites are observed for electrochemically mediated lignin oxidation [24]. In addition, the proprieties of Cu-based electrodes as electrochemical catalysts in alkaline media is an emerging topic [26–30], and the proprieties of this group of electrocatalysts for saccharides oxidation and the fact that the oxidation is mediated by Cu2+ species [29,30], highlights that maybe this can also be an interesting system for conversion of lignins. Electrocatalysis is a field that provides several in situ coupled techniques, such as vibrational spectroelectrochemical ones [31], which can provide insights into the catalyst behavior during the reaction, and the electrochemical measurements can answer questions about the active sites and oxidation paths, validating or complementing mechanisms, such as the ones presented in Scheme 1. These analyses are difficulted in pressurized reactors since they need to be sealed and just postmortem analysis are possible. Thus, this paper aims to establish a correlation between two different heterogeneous catalysis approaches, thermocatalysis, in which the energy is provided by heating the reactor [32], and electrocatalysis, with energy provided by electricity [33]. To do so, we selected CuO as the heterogeneous catalyst for the LOR and, developed a better understanding of the transformations on both catalytic processes, using material characterization techniques, such as electron microscopy, Spectro (electrochemical) Raman techniques, and electrochemical experiments, which will provide tools to optimize (electro)chemical reactors for enhanced lignin oxidative depolymerization. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals All solutions were prepared using ultrapure water (Milli-Q® system). The lignin was obtained as described in 2.3 and after that, dissolved in 2 mol L−1 KOH (Sigma-Aldrich). The final lignin concentration was 3 g L−1. CuO used was commercialized by Synth. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The catalyst was characterized by scanning electronic microscopy (SEM), Leo 440. The surface area was measured by physisorption (Quantachrome Nova 1000e), using 10 h of degasification at 200 °C, leading to a surface area density of 16.23 m2 g−1 and an average porous diameter of 2.15 nm. 2.3 Lignin extraction Because of its energetic matrix, Brazil is the biggest producer of sugarcane, consequently producing tons of bagasse annually. Sugarcane bagasse, a lignocellulosic biomass, is treated as a waste but can be used in biorefineries and thus, the valorization of its lignin is a topic of high importance. For this purpose, we opted to use lignin from sugarcane bagasse obtained from ethanol fuel production facilities. Isolated lignins are not as prone to oxidative depolymerization as the native ones [7]. However, as the main goal of this work is to get a better understanding of the role of the catalyst in the process, using native, in situ, lignin as in the emerging oxidative catalytic fractionation (OCF), brings complications. Hence, we opted for isolating lignin by the Pepper method. This method is carried out in mild conditions and the lignin isolated is less degraded than when isolated by conventional methods resembling the native lignin structure. With this approach, we can have a closer look at how the catalyst interacts with the macromolecule and this could bring some light to the role of catalysts not only in the oxidation of isolated lignin but also in OCF processes. For that, initially, the sugarcane bagasse was washed and let to dry, then ground in a knife mill and the fraction of granulometry between 40 and 60 mesh was subjected to extraction in a Soxhlet extractor using a cyclohexane/ethanol solution (1:1, v/v), for 15 h, for the extractives’ removal. The lignin extraction was carried out at reflux for 4 h in a solution of dioxane/2 N hydrochloric acid (9:1) at boiling temperature (around 95 °C), with a solid/liquid ratio of 1/10 (v/m). At the end of the extraction, the material was filtered, the solid was transferred to a beaker, washed with a dioxane-water solution (9:1), under mechanical stirring, and filtered again. The washing procedure was repeated 3 times. The filtrates were neutralized with sodium bicarbonate, pooled, and concentrated by solvent drying under low pressure to approximately 150 mL of solution. The concentrate was then added to 2 L of water under stirring, causing the lignin to precipitate. The solution containing the precipitated lignin was centrifuged and the settled solid was left to dry in an oven at 45 °C [34]. The isolated macromolecule structure was investigated by HSQC NMR as described by Rinken et al. [35] The main interunit linkages were quantified as the number of linkages per 100 aromatic units with Eq. 1. (1) Moiety / 100 Ar = V moiety V pFA 2 + V G 2 + 0.5 × V S 2 , 6 + V H 2 , 6 + V pCA 2 , 6 + V pB 2 , 6 × 100 Where Vmoiety is the integration of the signal of the α position of the interunit linkage; It should be noted that VS(2,6) takes into consideration the presence of S′ units. The content of each aromatic main precursor was calculated based on the same equation. However the Vmoiety used was S(2,6) divided by two for S units, H(2,6) divided by two for H, pCA(2,6) divided by two for pCA, pB(2,6) divided by two for pB, pFA (2) for FA and G(2) for G. Additional information about the 2D NMR is given on the Support Information. 2.4 Thermocatalysis oxidation For thermocatalysis investigation, the liquid phase was composed of 0.150 g of lignin, solubilized in 50 mL of a 2 mol L−1 NaOH solution, which resulted in a 3 g L−1 lignin solution. After that, it was loaded into a 100 mL reactor, to the solution was added 0.015 g of CuO. The reactor was closed and, at room temperature, pressurized with 1, 2.5, 5, 7.5, and 10 bar, being the first related to the ambient atmosphere, and the following resultant of the synthetic air addition. The reactor was then heated to 180 °C and maintained at this temperature under magnetic stirring (300 rpm) for 1 h. At the end of the reaction, the reactor was cooled in an ice bath to room temperature. The reactor contents were subjected to centrifugation to separate the catalyst from the solution. The catalyst was washed with 1% NaOH, then washed with water until neutral pH and left to dry in an oven at 50 °C. The reaction solution was then acidified with H2SO4 until pH 2 and subjected to two extraction steps with 50 mL of ethyl acetate. The aqueous fraction was discarded, and the organic fraction was dried under low pressure, obtaining an oil that was solubilized in acetonitrile and analyzed by GC-FID to quantify the monoaromatic compounds. External standards were used for the preparation of analytical curves for target monophenols. From the concentration of monophenol in the lignin oil solution, the yield, based on the initial mass of lignin, was calculated by Eq. 2. (2) Yield wt . % = C m g L × V ( L ) iL ( g ) × 100 % In which Cm is the concentration of the monophenol m in the solution, V is the volume of the solution and iL is the initial mass of lignin used for the reaction. All measurements were done in redundancy to ensure the reproducibility. 2.5 Electrochemical methods All electrochemical experiments were performed in a three-electrode cell, the working one was a glassy carbon disk (d = 4.5 mm), the auxiliary or counter electrode a large area graphite bar, and the reference, an encapsulated H2 bubble into a Luggin capillary with a Pt contact, against which all potentials in this work are referenced, VRHE. The working electrode was mechanically polished using alumina suspensions of 1 and 0.25 µm diameters and after that, cleaned with ultrapure water in an ultrasonic bath. It was modified by the drop-casting of 20 µL of 3.4 mg µL−1 CuO suspension. The electrode was then dried with a thermal blower, followed by the binder casting, 10 µL of 0.5% (m/m) Nafion® solution. The electrolyte was the same liquid phase used in the thermocatalysis experiments. All solutions were previously purged by 30 min of Ar bubbling and the experiments were performed at room temperature. The potential perturbation program was controlled by an Autolab potentiostat/galvanostat (PGSTAT320N) with an electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) control modulus. For the multi-frequency Mott-Schottky (mf-MS) analysis, the electrode was firstly let to rest at open circuit potential (OCP) and when it was stabilized, the potential was sinusoidally disturbed with a 10 mV amplitude and frequencies from 100 kHz down to 100 mHz, 10 points per decade. After that, a direct potential step was applied to − 200 mV vs. OCP for 10 s and then, around this DC potential, disturbed between 100 and 1 kHz, with the same amplitude and point distribution. This procedure was repeated until 200 mV vs. OCP, with steps of 25 mV. For the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) estimative, cyclic voltammetry was applied between 0.8 and 1.1 VRHE, a pure capacitive potential window. The scan rate varied between 5 and 1000 mV s−1. The current values measured at 0.9 VRHE, during the positive and negative scans, were tabled and the absolute average between these two values was considered for each scan rate and assumed to be the capacitive current values. More details on the data analysis are provided in the Support Discussion 1, in the Support Information file. The ECSA and the mf-MS were measured before and after step potential perturbations. These experiments were performed using 5 mL of electrolyte and the potentials were set constant for 3 h. After that, the electrolyte was collected, and acidified until pH 2 with H2SO4, leading to remaining lignin precipitation. After that, 5 mL of ethyl acetate was added and a three-phase system took place, the upper one organic, the middle, solid, and the bottom, aqueous. The aqueous and solid fractions were discarded, and the organic fraction was dried under low pressure, obtaining an oil that was solubilized in acetonitrile and analyzed by GC-FID to quantify the monoaromatic compounds. Since the electrochemical cell used in this study is related to a fundamental investigation, the total mass yield obtained was very low. Because of it, the faradaic efficiency (FE) was selected. FE is understood as the percentage of current that was used to obtain each product: (3) FE = n F N prod Q exp x 100 In which FE is the faradaic efficiency, in %, n is the number of electrons involved in the generation of each product, F is the Faraday’s constant, Nprod is the number of mols of product quantified by GC-FID and Qexp is the experimental total charge obtained by the current transient integration. In such a way, the charge related to the generation of each product is considered by the upper part of Eq. 3, considering n = 2 for aldehydes and ketones, as can be deduced from Scheme 1. All measurements were done in redundance, to assure that the data could be reproducible. 2.6 Raman For Raman spectroscopy, it was used a LabRam HR Evolution micro-Raman spectrometer (Horiba Jobin-Yvon), a solid-state laser operating at 633 nm, a standard grating (600gr/mm), and an EMCCD detector (Synapse EM). The samples were excited with low laser intensity (∼2 mW) to avoid overheating. A 50 × objective (Olympus, MPlan N) was used to focus the laser on the sample. The spectra were collected in an acquisition time of 20 s and 10 accumulations. The working electrode was an Au plate (30 ×15 mm), modified by drop casting, as in 2.5. The measurements were replicated to be sure of data reproducibility. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Sugarcane lignin structure Lignin oxidation is affected by the molecular structure. The aromatic composition of sugarcane bagasse Pepper lignin can be correlated to the mono phenolics yield derived from each lignin unit. Meanwhile, the interunit linkages can impact the oxidation yield, more specifically, lignins with a high content of β-O-4 linkages lead to higher mono phenolics yields. Thus, to assess the structural features in Pepper lignin isolated from the sugarcane bagasse fiber, used throughout the experiments presented in this work, HSQC NMR [35] was performed. Lignin's main structural features were analyzed in two key regions, the oxygenated aliphatic region (δC/δH 50–90/2.5–6.0 ppm) and aromatic region (δC/δH 100–150/6.0–8.0 ppm) ( Fig. 1). Signal identification was based on several previous works [36–39]. The δH/δC shifts for each identified structure is shown in Table S1. The aromatic region showed that the lignin consists of S, G, and H units, in addition to p-coumarate (pCA), FA ferulate, and p-hydroxybenzoate (pB). The presence of such structures is consistent with the characteristics of herbaceous lignins [36,39,40]. The aromatic structures as well as the main linkages between the lignin units were quantified as the number of linkage or aromatic structures per 100 aromatic units. It should be noted that pCA, FA, pB, and Cα oxidized S units (S′) were considered in the total aromatics count. Table 1 summarizes the aromatic composition of the lignin as well as the main interunit bonds identified by the HSQC. S units were found to be the major aromatic moiety in the lignin, with 46.8 S units per 100 aromatic units (Ar), followed by pCA, with 29.3 pCA per 100 Ar. This is following previous reports on the characterization of similar lignins [36,37]. The pCA is incorporated into the lignin structure mainly through the esterification of the hydroxyls in the γ position [41]. Etherified γ positions β-O-4 linkages (β-O-4′) can be observed in the spectra. It is worth noting that the content of G is 15.0 units per 100 Ar, while H units appear at 1.2 units per 100 Ar. In the oxygenated aliphatic region, common lignin linkages were identified and quantified based on 100 Ar. Three main lignin linkages were identified, β-O-4 linkages, phenylcoumaran (β-5), and resinol (β-β). β-O-4 is the major interunit linkage (21.8 linkages per 100 Ar), followed by phenylcoumaran (1.1 linkage per 100 Ar) which has a similar content as resinol (1.0 linkage per 100 Ar). During lignin isolation, interunit linkages are cleaved releasing smaller lignin fragments that are solubilized. Predominantly, β-O-4 linkages are cleaved because of their lower bond enthalpy and high content [42,43]. The Pepper method for lignin isolation is mild and because of that, the lignin obtained is less degraded than lignins isolated by conventional methods such as Kraft or Soda processes. As a result, the Pepper method preserves some of the native β-O-4 linkages in lignin, and the isolated lignin shows a high content of β-O-4 linkage and a low content of C-C linkages. The content pCA and pFA determined is considerably high for native lignin [44], but even though mild conditions were applied for the isolation of lignin, these structures are incorporated in the biomass through ester bonds which is easily cleaved in acidic conditions and low temperatures. The Pepper method carried out in an acid medium, promotes the hydrolyses of ester bonds and the release of pCA and pFA, leading to a higher content of such structures in the isolated lignin. 3.2 Thermocatalysis vs. electrocatalysis products distribution Lignin thermocatalytic oxidation reaction (LTOR) was performed with different synthetic air pressures, for controlling the oxygen partial pressure. After the reactions, the catalyst used in each reaction was isolated and characterized. Different monophenols related to different lignin monomers, as well as different functionalities, like aldehydes and ketones, were detected and quantified by GC-FID. The monophenolic yields (Eq. 2) are shown in Fig. 2. In all LTOR measurements, monophenolic aldehydes are the major products, with only small amounts of ketones being produced. The addition of synthetic air led to an increase in the total yield up to a maximum, at around 2.5 bar, this trend is observed in aldehydes and ketones. This result shows that oxygen is of paramount importance for the oxidation of lignin, and it agrees with previous results [18,45]. However, once these products are formed, they can be degraded in the presence of oxygen. Previous reports suggest that the oxidized monophenols can undergo ring opening, leading to aliphatic carboxylic acids or through radical condensation [18,45]. Higher oxygen concentration favors these side reactions, in the conditions applied herein, 2.5 bar of synthetic air was the optimum point, with the higher monophenol yield, a further increase in the initial pressure led to a decrease in yield due to the instability of these products in such conditions [45]. Individual yield varies independently of each other because of differences in the relative stability of each monophenol. Reactions with pressure lower than 5 bar presented products originating from the oxidation of S units as the main products, however with 7.5 and 10 bar, products originating from H units are the majority. This is a result of the different stability of the products obtained once products from S units are the ones that present the lower stability in the presence of oxygen, while H products are more stable. Furthermore, it is worth noting that in all LTOR, the yield of products originating from H units is higher than the yield of those originating from G units. Besides differences in the relative stability of each product, this result is also related to the composition of lignin (Table 1). As determined from HSQC analysis, the lignin was enriched in pCA. This structure, as well as H units, presents unsubstituted carbons in positions 3 and 5 of the aromatic ring and the oxidation of pCA can lead to p-hydroxybenzaldehyde and p-hydroxyacetophenone [46], products also obtained from the oxidation of H units. Therefore, the yield of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde higher than the yield of vanillin is consistent with the content of pCA and the content of G units in the Pepper lignin. Syringaldehyde, obtained from the oxidation of S units, is the major product in low-pressure LTOR. This result reflects the high content of this unit in the lignin used. However, regarding their relative stability in presence of oxygen, among the aldehydes obtained, syringaldehyde is the one with the lowest stability, followed by vanillin and lastly by p-hydroxybenzaldehyde [45]. Thus, at lower pressures, the individual yields can be related to the content in the lignin of the units that originated each of the aldehydes, while at higher partial pressure of oxygen the relative stability of each product obtained also play a role in the individual yields. For the lignin electro-oxidation reaction (LEOR), similar yields were obtained, as can be seen in Fig. 2B for mild oxidative conditions (I/t transients in Fig. S1). It is important to remember that for electrochemical measurements we considered the FE and not the mass yield, as explained in session 2.5. In the literature, the use of FE is not very often seen for lignin electrochemical oxidation. Many papers used a full electrochemical cell (electrolyzer), and presented only the mass proportion between the products, not a yield; the current density, and electrolysis time [24]. For most electrodes used, the preferential products were vanillin and syringaldehyde, both aldehydes. In some cases, using PbO electrodes, some aromatic acids are the main products [24]. Qualitatively, the product distribution presented for CuO is comparable to the observed for Ni and Co electrodes, even though the potential conditions for those electrodes were not fully provided [24]. For comparison among literature data, the vegetal species used as lignin source must be considered, since they can have different monomeric unities distribution. Therefore, it would make more sense to group the FE into organic functions such as aldehydes and ketones. The FE can be ordered, in general, as aldehydes > ketones, like the one observed for the LTOR’s yield (Fig. 2). In addition, for both catalytic processes, the generation of aldehydes is higher at mild oxidative conditions, around 25 or 20% for mass yield at padd = 2.5 and 5 bar, in Fig. 2A and in FE at 1.5 and 1.65 VRHE, in Fig. 2B, respectively. After these maxima, both decreased, which could be related to products' further oxidation to more oxidized species or even the mineralization of lignin. Anyway, the FE of all monophenols is, at maximum, around 30%, showing that other species are also generated by side reactions. Some of those by-products can be based on dimers, containing two phenolic rings [25]. But even when these products are considered, the total yield (m/m) reported in the literature is below 30% and can be reported as low as 1% [47], or around 25% for all products generated [24,25,48,49]. In this way, their low FE obtained in total, can be due to other side reactions that were not considered in these publications, and since the potentials are more positive than 1.23 VRHE, the oxygen evolution cannot be ignored as side reaction. It is interesting to remember that both systems presented a higher selectivity for breaking the Cα-Cβ bond (Fig. 2). In this way, it is logical to think that they would follow a reaction pathway like the proposed in Scheme 1A, but adding the fundamental steps of a heterogenous catalyzed reaction (Langmuir-Hinshelwood or Eley-Rideal). The main differences between both product distributions are related to selectivity for some monomers. Thermocatalysis was more selective for the S unities until 5 bar, while the electrocatalysis initially presented a higher selectivity to H unities and the less positive potentials presented a higher selectivity to Cβ-Cγ bonds, even though the activity at these potentials were lower. Since in both cases a higher selectivity for aldehydes is observed, the same Cα-Cγ bond breaking is expected, so there is a high possibility of both mechanisms being the same. In this way, a closer look at what is going on with the catalyst can provide more insights and the electrochemical techniques can bring a better comprehension of both systems. However, due to the nature of the thermocatalysis experiments performed in this work, in situ analysis of the thermoreactor is not possible. Because of this, postmortem analysis will be the only possible way. The main issue with the postmortem analysis is that the thermocatalyst investigation becomes more speculative since it would assume that the catalyst morphological and chemical constitution would be the same during the reaction and after its isolation, which is probably not true. This fact will be further highlighted and better contextualized according to the used technique in the next section. 3.3 Catalyst evaluation For the catalyst investigation, the first step was to investigate the changes in morphology due to LOR. For that, SEM images of the CuO powder before and after its utilization as catalyst were obtained. For the electrocatalyst, the drop casted material was carefully transferred to the sample holder. The images are presented in Fig. 3. The fresh catalyst (Fig. 3A) is porous. When this material is used for LEOR (Fig. 3B), or LTOR (Fig. 3C and S-S8) the morphology indeed changes and in different ways. The first idea that came to one’s mind is that it is reaction evidence, the catalyst is taking part in the LEOR. Since the catalyst is initially in the most oxidative form of Cu2+ and is reduced to Cu+/0, while the lignin is oxidized. During this, the ionic radii change from 0.57 Å for Cu2+ in CuO [50] to 0.60 Å for Cu+ in Cu2O [50] or 1.35 Å for metallic copper [51]. These differences are discrete for the Cu2+ and Cu+, especially because the O atom should also be considered for the crystallographic base. In this case, one should consider the crystallographic unit cell of these materials. For such analysis, X-ray diffraction would be a suitable analysis, however, since copper is a material that promptly reacts with atmospheric oxygen and can be re-oxidized [52,53]. In this way, postmortem analysis for copper materials is not the best alternative. That is why we are going to consider the SEM analysis qualitatively, and this issue will be remembered before the Raman analysis, later in this section. Anyway, the CuO unity cell is a monoclinic one, while Cu2O is cubic [54], as well as the Cu0. The dimensions of such cells are also very particular and differ from each other by at least 0.5 Å, considering the biggest cell parameter from CuO [54]. Such differences should, indeed, affect the material morphology due to the stress of these phase changes. All these transformations resulted, in all cases, in surface area changes. Figs. S7-S8 show that the highest added pressure experiments resulted in more compacted material. The experiments at lower pressures (Fig. 3C and S5-S6), as well as the electrochemical one (Fig. 3B), resulted in materials that are probably related to higher surface area, and this can be related to the higher efficiency to monoaromatic aldehydes. For the final copper material, the BET area was not possible to be obtained, since the possibility of remaining sulfur contaminants from the biomass can result in serious damage to the equipment used in this work. However, the LEOR has been shown, so far, to be like the LTOR. In this case, the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) measurements can be used to aid this investigation. In this case, we decided to use the triangular perturbation, as described in 2.5. The obtained j/E profiles are presented in Fig. S2 and then analyzed in Fig. S3. The area variation was analyzed by comparing the ECSA before and after the step potential perturbation. The changes are shown in Fig. 4. In Fig. 4 the catalyst area significantly increases at the most active potential window, with a maximum increment of 80% at the same potential reported in Fig. 3B. After that, at more positive potentials, the area increment became negative, which can be related to two reasons: (i) the catalyst became more compact, due to increment in particle sizes and coalescence, as shown in Figs. S7 and S8 and (ii) oxygen bubbles originated by the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) can detach some of the active material. Reason (ii) is observed just for the LEOR since OER became a competitive reaction at such oxidative conditions and is probably the main reason for the negative area increment observed in Fig. 4. This is also the reason why some black powder can be observed at the cell bottom after the full procedure. However, the effect of both hypotheses cannot be neglected, since even at 2.0 VRHE, where OER is expected to be present, a small area increment can be observed. Of course, just looking at similar selectivity and SEM images not much can be understood about the comparison between thermo- and electrocatalysis. That is why other measurements, such as spectroscopic ones, are needed. Raman spectroscopy can be very important, since it is sensitive to moieties, such as Cu-O, and it can be detected and investigated. In Fig. 5 the Raman spectra related to the heterogenous (Fig. 5A) and electrochemical (Fig. 5B) catalysis are presented. It is worth saying that the first case was measured ex-situ, while the second, was in situ, so some shifts in the band’s centers are expected and probably different moieties can be observed. One of the reasons for such differences is that if the active catalytic site containing Cu2+ centers is reduced during the LTOR and even after the reaction is over, some of these metallic centers can still be present. If this is the case, the transport between the experimental setup and the Raman microscope can be enough for the atmospheric air to oxidize these sites to Cu+/2+ due to the presence of oxygen [52]. In Fig. 5A a doublet between 200 and 400 cm−1 is always present, however, their centers shift with the additional pressure. For the fresh material, three bands were observed, one centered at 280 cm−1, related to CuO Ag moiety [27,55,56], at 328 and 607 cm−1 the B1 g and B2 g, respectively, are detected [55,56]. When the catalyst is exposed to lignin in the reactor, the CuO B2 g-related band is no longer observed, mainly due to the strong fluorescence of this macromolecule. Depending on the added pressure, the B1 g bands are also not observed, but a doublet is still observed below 400 cm−1. This is the case for 1 and 2.5 bar, in which a band, attributed to Cu2O [27], centered at 220 and 218 cm−1, for the lower and higher pressures, in order, is observed. For the materials that were exposed to 1 bar, the second band was too broad to be attributed to B1 g alone. In addition, the non-gaussian shape also suggests that more than one band is present at that region, and that is why this band was deconvoluted (Fig. S9). By doing so, it was possible to detect a band centered at 278 cm−1, attributed to Ag, and a larger one centered at 326 cm−1, related to B1 g [27,55,56]. For the one at 2.5 bar, a band at lower Raman shifts, centered at 206 cm−1 was interpreted as a related signal [57], as well. The observance of Cu2O is expected by the monoeletronic oxidation proposed in the literature [15,20], in this way, the oxidant, CuO, is monoelectronic reduced to Cu2O[53,58,59] and, this species is further re-oxidized to CuO, by the reaction conditions. Through this process, the crystallographic structure is rapidly changing, and so, the morphology, as discussed in Fig. 3. However, there is no clear evidence that the Cu+ observed is from the Cu2+ reduction by monoelectronic steps, or if a two-electron step or two consecutive monoelectronic ones are present in the LTOR. If one of these two hypotheses is true, Cu2+ can be reduced to Cu0, directly or by two steps. In this case, the remaining metallic centers can be oxidized by the atmosphere, as previously suggested. In higher pressures Cu2O related bands are absent. In this case, the higher oxidative power of the reactor can be enough to re-oxidize all Cu+/0 centers back to Cu2+. At 5 and 7.5 bar the CuO Ag and B1 g bands were observed around 293 and 340 cm−1, in order, while at 10 bar both bands were lightly red shifted to 290 and 338 cm−1. It would be expected that smaller CuO particles would be related to redshifts in Raman signals [55,56], however, the 10 bar experiment resulted in a compacter and coalesced material, so bigger sizes (Fig. S8) and the most redshifted signals were observed. In the electrochemical environment (Fig. 5B), just bands related to CuO Ag and B1 g around 297 and 345 cm−1, respectively, were observed. These bands were stationary with bias potential. Comparing the band center with the ones observed from the thermocatalyst, just 5 and 7.5 bar provided similar conditions to the electrochemical environment. During the electrochemical experiment, no Cu2O-related signal was observed. This fact has two interpretations, (i) the electrochemical mechanism occurs by the generation of Cu0, instead of Cu+, and (ii) Cu2+ is rapidly regenerated and the equipment is not sufficiently resolved to detect such species. Due to the differences in spectral measurement conditions, band centers may not provide the best comparison that one could do with the present data. However, the Ag-related bands present changes in full width at half-maximum (FWHM), and this can be related to changes in the crystallinity of these samples [55,60]. To verify if these changes agree between the thermo- and electrocatalysis, the Ag FWHM was plotted against the O2 partial pressure and bias potential (Fig. 5C). For the cases in which the Ag band could not be separated by eye from the B1 g, deconvolution was used (Fig. S9). The FWHM initially decreases, in both cases, around 20 cm−1, being the largest band always from the starting material. The minimum was observed at 5 bar and between 1.35 and 1.70 VRHE, this similarity agrees with the fact that this synthetic air pressure is the one that presented closer band centers (Fig. 5) and surface area increment (Fig. 4). This should mean that similar reactions are taking place at these conditions, and thus comparable mechanisms, the Cα-Cβ cleavage by reaction pathways that can be like the proposed in Scheme 1. The presented data, so far, allowed us to compare the experimental conditions and to find the ones in which the thermo- and electrocatalysis merge. However, we do not understand, so far, the catalyst behavior during the LOR. Due to similarities between both cases, we decided to apply electrochemical techniques advantages to investigate the CuO during LOR. For that, we recall from the experimental session, item 2.5, that EIS measurements were performed before and after the LEOR. With these measurements, we were able to apply Mott-Schottky (MS) analysis [61–66], and with so, the semiconductor properties of CuO will be investigated and provide more data for the comprehension of previous presented analysis. To be sure if the single frequency or traditional MS investigation is suitable to our system, we needed, initially, to investigate a broad frequency range (100k to 100 mHz) EIS datum. This is an investigation that should be done in the absence of faradaic processes, so the open circuit potential (OCP) was selected for this initial test. In the EIS data at OCP, three time-constants (TC) could be observed, being one at high frequencies, and related to the oxide layer, and being represented by a capacitive element in parallel to a resistive one. The second TC, at intermediate frequencies, is related to the double layer capacitance and the charge transfer resistance, while the last TC, at low frequencies, was attributed to a finite mass transport element, a Warburg short (Ws). By the non-ideal semi-circle shape of the oxide and double layer related TCs, constant phase elements (CPEs) were suggested for the fitting, and the result can be seen in Fig. 6A. Due to the non-ideal oxide’s capacitive behavior, the single-frequency MS cannot be used, and the multi-frequency MS (mf-MS) was selected [67–69]. For the mf-MS investigation, we are interested in the high-frequency TC, so the EIS measurements were restricted between 100 and 1 kHz. The data was fitted using an EEC containing one resistor, related to the electrolyte, in series with the oxide TC (CPEox in parallel with a resistor, Rox). The EEC, as well as an example of fitting, is presented in Fig. 6B. The CPE impedance values cannot be used for the MS equation (Eq. 4), mainly due to the different exponents (β) observed. (4) 1 C 2 = 2 ε ε 0 e N A E − E fb + kT e In Eq. 4, C is the oxide capacitance, ε the material relative dielectric permittivity, ε0 the vacuum one, e the elementary charge, NA the charge carriers’ population, E the bias potential, Efb the flat-band one, k the Boltzmann constant and T the temperature. The different β values made the direct comparison between the CPEox invalid, and in addition, a capacitance value needs to be investigated by Eq. 4. Because of this, the CPE impedances need to be converted into effective capacitances (C′). For that, the Hsu and Mansfeld’s model (Eq. 5) [70] was selected, since this should be the best expression to consider the oxides volumetric imperfections [71]. (5) C′ = P ox 1 β ox R ox 1 − 1 β ox In Eq. 5, C′ is the effective capacitance, Pox the CPEox result, βox the CPE exponent, and Rox the oxide resistance. After that, the Mott-Schottky plot was built, considering C′−2 vs. E (Fig. 6D), and for all the presented data, crescent lines were obtained, signalizing that the CuO used here is better classified as an n-type intrinsic semi-conductor than a p-type one, as expected for copper (I or II) oxides [72,73]. However, morphological changes in such semiconductors can provide n-type materials [74]. In this case, the treatments that the material suffered before being used probably were the reason for these changes and increment in n-type charge carriers [75,76]. For intrinsic n-type semiconductors two kinds of charge carriers are expected: (i) substitution of base cations for ones of higher valance, so Cu2+ by Cu3+ or (ii), oxygen vacancies (Ovac). The first option is not probable, since Cu3+ is not a stable species, but the second is not just probable, but expected to be related to the active sites of this catalyst, due to the missing bonds, making the Cu2+ sites more energetic than the Cu2+-O ones [75–79]. In this way, the NA in Eq. 4 should be related to the Ovac population in the catalyst. Relating the linear slopes, obtained by Eq. 4, for before and after the electrolysis, it is possible to relate to the change in the Ovac population due to LEOR (Eq. 6). (6) MS fresh slope MS aged slope = N A aged N A fresh For tracking the relation between Ovac and the selectivity, we plotted the N A aged N A fresh vs. Eox (Fig. 6D) and the Ovac population increases in the same potential window in which the selectivity and area increment are higher, as well as the FWHM is narrower. During the Cα-Cβ bonds breaking, the Cu2+ centers would be reduced to Cu+ or Cu0. The redox cycles suffered by the Cu centers are related to the catalyst oxygen evacuation, since Cu2+ is coordinated to 4 O atoms in CuO and Cu+ to 2 O atoms in Cu2O [54]. This changes the total stoichiometry in the unity cell from 1:1 to 2:1, as well as the crystal structure, from monoclinic to cubic [54]. Support Discussion 2, in the support information, explains in more detail what oxygen vacancies are, what is their importance, and how they can be generated. In this point, it is important to recall from there that all these changes will induce more crystalline heterogeneity and, as a consequence, more borders between these heterogeneities. These borders present lower Ovac formation energy and help to understand how mild conditions as the application to a reaction can change the Ovac population. The Ovac increment at the most active potential window suggests that a positive feedback loop [58] is taking place. The lignin is oxidized at an Ovac, reducing the Cu center, and, consequently, changing the coordination in the surroundings. The bias potential, in turn, makes the Cu+/0 centers go back to Cu2+. During these processes, other centers that were not evacuated were also reduced, and oxidized, making the regenerated material more evacuated than the original. In this observation, the Ovac sites are examples of autocatalytic species. Raman spectroscopy is a technique usually used for oxygen vacancy investigation for oxide materials, such as silica [80], ceria [81–83] and titania [84]. In many of these works, a signal related to the Ovac is pointed out by the authors [80,83–85]. However, it should be highlighted that the vibration detected is normally related to the O-metal stretching, and as pointed out by some authors [55], this movement is centered in the O atom, the lightest atom. In this sense, the increase in Ovac population should not be related to an enhancement of Raman signal, or the observance of a new band, but to a decrease in intensity or a band shift. In ceria, it is said that a band enlargement is observed [82,83,86] and a red shift can also be observed for some materials, like ZnO [85]. Observing the electrochemical in situ Raman measurements in Fig. 5B, the bands were observed as stationary, and if some small shift is observed, it is in the blue direction, especially in the potential region related to the higher Ovac population (Fig. 6D). In addition, when the thermocatalysis material is considered (Fig. 5A), in all conditions the Ag-related bands were blue-shifted. The vibrational bands' frequency expression is related to the vibrational spring constant by Eq. 7. (7) ν = 1 c 2 π k μ Where ν is the vibrational frequency, c the light speed, k the spring constant, and µ the oscillator reduced mass. In this way, the stronger the spring, the higher is ν. The absence of some oxygen atoms induces a higher electron population in the conducting band, so more free electrons can be the reason for the k enhancement and consequently, the blue shift. Now, regarding the band enlargement, it can also be related to the opposite direction, the conditions with smaller FWHM (Fig. 5C) were the ones related to higher Ovac population (Fig. 6D), and higher aldehydes production (Fig. 2). It makes sense that the Ovac sites would be preferable to LEOR since the Cα-Cβ bond could easily reach those. However, the mechanism proposed in the literature does not predict a Cu-C bond generation [15,20]. It also, does not predict that the O atoms in the carboxyl should be originated from the O2. Nevertheless, in the electrochemical data and for the reaction at 1 bar, the same products were detected, so an Eley-Rideal mechanism should not satisfy the O source and the no adsorption. A Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism should not just justify the O source, but also the Ovac relation and would make the organic radical previously proposed to be in solution, to be stabilized by adsorption, allowing a selective Cα-Cβ bond cleavage. The data presented here is not enough to be certain about the mechanism, however, the importance of Ovac sites can be a suggestion for Langmuir-Hinshelwood paths [58]. 3.4 Electrocatalysis As shown until now, LTOR and LEOR are related to the same catalytic pathway, involving Ovac as the active sites, and these species' generation is autocatalytic. The selectivity at mild oxidative conditions is also similar. The LTOR reactor makes it difficult to analyze the reaction pathways, so the fact that LEOR follows the same paths suggests that electrochemical techniques should be of great aid for the mechanistic understanding of this reaction. Firstly, to investigate LEOR, the working electrode was inserted into the electrochemical cell, and a triangular potential perturbation program was applied, as presented in Fig. 7A. As can be seen, a small oxidative current can be observed, with an onset potential (Eonset) around 1.2 VRHE. This value is considerably less positive than that observed for Pb-based electrodes, around 1.7 VSHE [23], which is already in the OER potential window for such electrodes. For NiFeCo alloys, the Eonset at room temperature can be found to be around the same, 1.7 VRHE [87]. This 1.7 VRHE was already reported in the literature as a gain, since for some pure Ni electrodes, Eonset can be around 2.1 VRHE [58]. For the kinetic evaluation of LEOR, the Tafel plot (Fig. 7B) was also made. For that, the steady current values observed in the step potential experiments (Fig. S1) were used. The Tafel region was observed to be above 1.5 VRHE and the observed slope was 148 mV. The discussion of LEOR in the literature normally does not present Tafel data [88–92], despite being one of the most important quantities in the electrocatalytic reactions. With the Tafel slope, it is possible to obtain n(1-α), being n the number of electrons involved in the rate determinant step (rds) and (1-α) the complementary symmetry factor. With the data presented in Fig. 7B, the value of 0.40 can be obtained. This value is expected to be related to a monoelectronic step since a polyelectronic one would mean that (1-α) would be extremely small, and that would not make sense. In this sense, the previous discussions about the Cu species involved in the cycles may be clearer. If monoelectronic steps are the rds, Cu2+ is probably reduced to Cu+, and Cu2O being oxidized to Cu2+ and CuO are the expected Ovac generation cycles. 4 Conclusions It was shown that the oxidative behavior of lignin on CuO catalysts is similar for thermo- and electrocatalysis since both presented similar functional selectivity (more than 20% for monophenolic aldehydes, preferential Cα-Cβ bond breaking) at intermediate oxidative conditions, similar catalyst size after the LOR experiments and Raman spectroscopical behavior. The absence of band shifting due to the smaller particles was not initially comprehended, however, the interesting narrowing of the CuO’s Ag bands, which reached the minimum at highest yields/FE values (for LTOR and LEOR, in order), indicated that some other issues were needed to be comprehended. For that, the electrochemical techniques were of great support, showing the importance of Ovac for LOR. In this way, we related the narrowing to the higher electronic density due to these intrinsic charge carriers. By the volcano behavior with maximum selectivity, Ovac population, and minimum Ag FWHM, Ovac were also related to the active sites for LOR. coredata.dc:description: Biorefinery is gaining attention as a way to obtain several high-value products in a green approach. Biomass can be used to obtain fuels, like ethanol. The waste, rich in lignins, can be (electro)chemically transformed into monophenols and other fuels, like hydrogen. This macromolecule has a complex structure and the optimization of (electro)catalysts for its depolymerization is difficult, mainly because the lack of fundamental knowledge. Because of this, we decided to compare thermo and electrochemical catalysis, using identical reaction liquor and catalyst. The products were identified and quantified by GC-FID. Mild oxidative conditions generated more aldehydes, independently if it was under electrochemical conditions or not. To explore eventual mechanistic similarities, we investigated the catalyst by Raman spectroscopy and electronic microscopy. By them, a similar behavior was observed, the particles were less coalesced and the CuO-related bands were narrowed. After, by Mott-Schottky analysis, the oxygen vacancies were identified as the active sites.
coredata.dc:title: CuO as (electro)catalyst for lignin valorization
